awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Development of Broadly Efficacious Ribonucleic Acid Interference Triggers for Pesticides
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be to provide farmers with a new class of biotechnology-based pesticides for more affordable and environmentally benign crop production by addressing an unmet need: an efficacious, selective and safe pesticide. The project will focus on a pesticide for the diamondback moth (DBM), a pest that damages Brassica crops such as canola, cabbage, cauliflower and collards.  It is the most costly invasive crop pest worldwide, for which there is no effective solution with acceptable resistance management.  DMB has developed resistance to more than 90 active ingredients in conventional insecticides, i.e., almost every insecticide class known. If successful, this biotechnology platform will contribute to sustainable food production and enhanced biodiversity with minimal use of non-selective traditional pesticides associated with human health costs.  The goal is to develop a product that is efficacious, selective, and provides improved resistance management against field populations of DMB.

The intellectual merit of this SBIR Phase II project is the development of RNAi-based pesticide for the treatment of diamondback moth (Plutella xylostella) infestations in cruciferous crops.  In the last five years, there have been significant advances in the methods for the production of RNAi triggers that allow the manufacturing of these materials in large quantities and at a low price, which is required for broad agricultural applications. Topical RNAi-based pesticides have been demonstrated in the lab to be very selective with respect to the intended target. They also may be readily modified to combat developed pesticide resistance by target pests. However, due to low efficacy at economically attractive application rates, very few pests and no Lepidopteran insects are currently in the RNAi list of commercial targets. This project specifically addresses the challenges related to RNAi efficacy, and the development of the proposed technology could be applied to Lepidopteran control and other biotechnology applications. The outcome of the proposed research would provide the first example of a scalable RNAi-based insecticide targeting Plutella xylostella or any Lepidopteran.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Project addressed fundamental issues that have prevented the widespread application in agriculture of a scientific discovery for which the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded in 2006. The biologically active component discovered and used since then has been demonstrated to selectively kill agricultural pests under controlled laboratory and greenhouse conditions. However, it has also been found to be unstable in the field as well as in the digestive tract of most insect pests. Furthermore, it has properties that make it in most cases less efficacious than needed to be used effectively by farmers.

In this Project, NanoSUR was able to significantly improve the stability and the properties of such biologically active component by devising modification procedures that can be implemented at a cost compatible with agricultural applications. Furthermore, by so doing, new biologically active ingredients were produced. Such new active ingredients produced by NanoSUR were demonstrated efficacious in field trials conducted in California and Florida for the protection of cabbage and broccoli from the most damaging invasive insect pest worldwide.

Such achievements have advanced scientific knowledge in an area of biology widely studied in search for solutions to the fundamental problems that have afflicted the active components discovered in 2006. Because the solutions discovered by NanoSUR have general applicability to most pests, they have significant potential to improve human well-being. NanoSUR’s new active ingredients are designed to be selective towards pests that damage the crops sprayed with them without modifying the genome of the protected crop nor the targeted pest. While efficacious against target pests, they are expected to be innocuous towards non target organisms, many of them beneficial to the crops as well as the environment. Thus, it is expected that the selectivity and the efficacy of NanoSUR’s active ingredients will result in their use for the protection of crops without negative effects for the farmers that use them, the consumers of food produced with them, and the environment.

 


Last Modified: 09/02/2023
Modified by: Juan Arhancet
